posts.author: extaz93
posts.content:
Hello everyone,

I want to bring a friend on EfU:R server, but he's really new to NWN, and after playing the game since day one, i'm still really a newbie at builds.

I would like to share a few basic efficient builds with him.
At first i thought about a basic human fighter, but frontliners on EfU are dying a lot and it might give him a lot of frustration early on.
On the other hand, clerics and spellcasters might be hard to play for a first character...
Maybe a bow ranger? But i actually never played a ranger in nwn...

Also, the really slow and capped leveling on EfU:R doesn't leave a lot of room for mistakes in the choice of feats...

So i'm asking for your help and ideas for a few basic newbie-friendly builds, capped at lvl 10 (and i actually never reached lvl 10 with any of my characters on EfU... Most powerful PC's are around lvl 7-8...)

PS : if you don't know anything about EfU, it is a low-magic PW, full PVP, set in the underdark. Most ennemies are goblins, troglodytes, ogres, minotaurs, gnolls, spiders...And each class has a few mechanical changes (see link) from main game.

https://www.efupw.com/forums/index.php?topic=35727.0
Thanks!

posts.author: Mirnaia
posts.content: I'm way too sleepy to work it out, but how about a zen archer druid, played my little army style? It's a lot harder to die when you can let your summons tank and you shoot from behind. Then again, your summons can also pull the entire map all at once. You mostly operate with summons and buffs, which is a gentle introduction to spellcasting, you're on a server so the xp reduction is less of a problem, and you have one very specific task to master: staying behind and learning how to use the keyboard shortcuts for issuing commands to your pets. It will also teach him about how the game handles monster attacks when there is more than one possible target. It will probably end up as a 9/1 druid/monk?

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Fighter 6/Barbarian 1/Rogue 3, might be good for that particular module.
The secret in low-level, low-magic modules, is to start really strong, and have a solid backbone to build around.

Race: Half-Orc
Alignment: Something neutral & NOT lawful, is Ideal

Abilities: (Str 20(22), Dex 10, Con 12, Int 13, Wis 08, Cha 06)
01) Fighter(01): Expertise, Wf: Battle-axe
02) Fighter(02): Power attack
03) Fighter(03): Cleave
04) Fighter(04): Ws: Battle-axe [STR+1]
05) Barbarian(01): fast movement, rage 1/day
06) Fighter(05): Blind-fight
07) Rogue(01):
08) Fighter(06): Improved Critical: Battle-axe, Knockdown, [STR +1]
09) Rogue(02): Improved Knockdown, evasion
10) Rogue(03):

There are a lot of things that are safer than this guy, but with a full-plate & shield, full-tumble ranks & expertise in his disposal he can certainly last for a good while, in the front lines.
And he hits hard, really hard with natural 22 Strength & Weapon specialization & 2d6 Sneak-attack & Improved Knockdown & UMD
He moves faster than a normal warrior should, which is always a bonus & makes gameplay easier & has Evasion
He is an enjoyable character overall because he hits consistently, he hits hard & has two attacks plus cleave
He can carry a lot of loot in case bags of holding are a rare commodity
He starts with 7AB right out of character creation

For real fun use a 2-hander & watch heads fall-off! (Compromises AC though, so maybe not the best choice if things are really tough)
There is also a mini-version of Mick's "Brawler Champion" (Ftr/Monk/CoT) that I made a while ago for level 10, but my search-fu isn't good enough as Stagmeister's & I can't find it at the moment.

posts.author: Thorsson
posts.content:
So, re-reading the first post again, puts me in mind of my first post in that thread. This is designing for a character that may never reach level 10 and, on a PW, who needs to be 'strong' every step of the way.

What is the best build depends somewhat on what he needs to do. Key questions I can think of are:

1. Will he need Rogue Skills? If there aren't traps or if he will always be in a party with a Rogue character, then the situation is different from soloing a lot in a trap-happy environment.
2. Will he largely be facing "grunts" (i.e. melee types) or will he have to be making lots of Saves? If the latter then CoT becomes more optimal.
3. Are there any "homebrew" changes?

My knowledge of NWN is beginner compared to these guys, but I've been playing D&D for over 40 years and much of that has been spent with low level builds. Here you will never be able to get in BAB11 and 3 normal attacks per round, but it is advantageous to get two attacks sooner than later. Fighters are great, because from the off they can wear the heaviest armor and use all shields. In the early levels AC is often king.

Frontliners are much easier to play than other builds. If they tend to die a lot, then you should concentrate on making them tough. But you probably need to say exactly what the main challengers are - if it's taking physical damage then you want lots of AC and lots of HP.

If we take Valerfor's 10-level Brawler then, I would say that maybe it is better as a Dwarf. You can drop Toughness from the plan and still have the same HPs (and +1 to your Fort Save), plus you get all the Dwarven Racial abilities, many of which are survival aids, including Darkvision, +2 v Spells and Poisons and the combat bonuses against Giants, Orcs and Goblinoids. You can probably drop Persuade from the skill set. You should also base the weapon choice on what is available and the foes faced, e.g. if crit immunes are limited, Scimitar may be a better pick. The one downside to the build is level 1 - Monks are not very survivable at first level; but I assume he'll be able to "leach" XP in a party.
